Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Integral Equations with Delay; Optimal Control and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will develop a new innovative approach to model complex dynamics processes in technology, biology, ecology, economics, and the environmental sciences. While many models have arisen in these disciplines, mathematical theory is far behind fast growing application needs. The distinguishing feature of the problems under study is the optimal control of endogenous delays. These delays reflect the age of individuals to be harvested or the lifetime of obsolete equipment to be replaced due to technological innovations. While such models have immense potential for applied sciences, prior use has primarily been restricted due to the assumption of constant delays. The use of variable endogenous delays will provide greater modeling flexibility and open new horizons in qualitative analysis of the models. Optimal control with endogenous delays will be reduced to the analysis of integral equations with unknown upper limits of integration. Such equations represent a completely new mathematical object and will be part of the study. Thus, the project outcomes will enhance both mathematics with new results in the optimal control and integral equations and applications with new investigation techniques relevant to applications.

Models based on equations with delay are currently employed by various interdisciplinary groups of scientists in economic growth theory, operations research, management sciences, environmental protection, life sciences, population biology, and related areas. The developed methods will be beneficial to these fields and lead to deeper analysis of many phenomena. As a consequence, the research will foster collaboration among scientists from different countries and disciplines and stimulate new contacts. Societal benefits include the ability to allocate usage of novel technological inventions and optimal management of natural resources under environmental and climate changes. The project also will attract attention of mathematical community to new applications and increase participation of African-American undergraduates in research. These students will be involved in all research activities and will present at conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report


Project Title: RUI: Integral Equations with Delay; Optimal Control and Applications
PI: Natali Hritonenko

Awardee: Prairie View A&M Research Foundation

Award Number: NSF-1009197

Period for the report: July 1, 2010-June 30, 2013


Mathematical modeling and optimal control theory have been successfully used to describe real-life phenomena, solve a wide range of applied problems, and make valuable predictions. The project concentrates on problems important to economics, biology, the environmental sciences, management, operations research, and production economics. Namely, the following problems are considered and corresponding models are constructed and studied: rational management and optimal harvesting in age- and size-structured biological populations,  economic growth with heterogeneous capital and resources, rational equipment replacement, sustainable development and environmental protection. Mathematically, all these models are described by means of integral and differential equations and present a new class of optimal control problems with state constraints. New investigation techniques for such problems are suggested. The obtained theoretical outcomes are compared with real data presented by collaborators and results obtained by a computer simulation. The interpretation of all project findings is provided.

The extensive interdisciplinary research provided in collaboration with prominent international researchers from France, Belgium, Spain, Ukraine, and Greece leads to new results in mathematical modeling, optimal control, mathematical economics, environmental sciences, and biomathematics.

A group of undergraduate African-American students has participated in each activity, submitted papers, made presentations and received awards for their talks. They have had  a one-hour meeting with the PI each week to discuss on-going research. The most active students received a financial support from the NSF grant.

In order to make research results available for the mathematical community, scientific audience, and general public and promote the NSF support, the obtained results of the successful research work are outlined in 22 talks at international mathematical and interdisciplinary conferences and 6 students’ talk and published in 16 papers and 6 conference proceedings. The NSF financial support is acknowledged in all papers and presentations.

 


Last Modified: 07/09/2013
Modified by: Natalia V Hritonenko
